item.title: Capital asset pricing model
item.description: Introduction to the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) The Capital Asset Market Pricing Model (CAPM) states that the return on a particular risky asset is related to returns of the ‘market’ as follows: Return(asset) = alpha + beta*Return(market)+error Here, I use several individual stocks as target from the end of 2018 till now (Oct 2020). myStocks <- c("AAPL","AMZN","MSFT","FB","SPY" ) %>% tq_get(get = "stock.prices", from = "2018-12-31", to = "2020-10-10") %>% group_by(symbol) str(myStocks) # examine the structure of the resulting data frame ## tibble [2,245 x 8] (S3: grouped_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.

item.title: Omega Group plc- Pay Discrimination
item.description: At the last board meeting of Omega Group Plc., the headquarters of a large multinational company, the issue was raised that women were being discriminated in the company, in the sense that the salaries were not the same for male and female executives. A quick analysis of a sample of 50 employees (of which 24 men and 26 women) revealed that the average salary for men was about 8,700 higher than for women.

item.title: Returns of financial stocks
item.description: You may find useful the material on finance data sources. We will use the tidyquant package to download historical data of stock prices, calculate returns, and examine the distribution of returns. We must first identify which stocks we want to download data for, and for this we must know their ticker symbol; Apple is known as AAPL, Microsoft as MSFT, McDonald’s as MCD, etc. The file nyse.csv contains 508 stocks listed on the NYSE, their ticker symbol, name, the IPO (Initial Public Offering) year, and the sector and industry the company is in.

item.title: About me
